titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Juan Domingo Perón papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by David Jacobs

did.abstract: The Juan Domingo Perón papers consist primarily of correspondence between Perón and his followers, conducted largely during the period of his exile in Madrid, Spain. Among the correspondents are many of the major figures of the Peronist movement, including trade union leaders in Argentina and exiled Peronist activists. The letters themselves contain detailed information about rivalries and intrigues among different Peronist factions, and they record the efforts of Perón's lieutenants as they sought both to curry favor in the eyes of their leader and to sustain the Peronist movement within Argentina. They also document the roles played by Isabel Perón and José Lopez Rega in the last years of Juan Perón's life.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Juan Domingo Perón Papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in intervals between 1958 and 2004.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

chronitem.event: Born, Province of Buenos Aires, Argentina
Entered military school, after graduation served in armed forces
Sent to Europe as a military observer; visited Italy and was favorably impressed by Benito Mussolini's fascist government
Participated in military coup against civilian government of Ramón Castillo and became head of Department of Labor
Became Vice President and Secretary of War
Married Eva Duarte, known as Evita Perón
Lived in exile, first in Panama and then in the Dominican Republic, eventually settling in Madrid, Spain
Married María Estela Martínez, known as Isabel Perón
Returned to Argentina and was elected president
Died. Isabel Perón succeeded him as president

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The Juan Domingo Perón papers consist primarily of correspondence between Perón and his followers, conducted largely during the period of his exile in Madrid, Spain. Among the correspondents are many of the major figures of the Peronist movement, including trade union leaders in Argentina and exiled Peronist activists. The letters themselves contain detailed information about rivalries and intrigues among different Peronist factions, and they record the efforts of Perón's lieutenants as they sought both to curry favor in the eyes of their leader and to sustain the Peronist movement within Argentina. They also document the roles played by Isabel Perón and José Lopez Rega in the last years of Juan Perón's life.

A significant part of the Correspondence series consists of letters exchanged between Perón and Pablo Vicente, a former colonel in the Argentinian army living in exile in Montevideo, Uruguay, who acted as a conduit for mail being sent to Perón from his followers in Argentina. These letters from supporters were left as they were originally arranged, among the correspondence from Vicente to Perón. Vicente's letters to Perón also include detailed analyses of political developments in Argentina, as well as Vicente's own assessments of internal tensions within the Peronist movement.

Other notable correspondents include John W. Cooke, who at one time seemed to be Perón's heir apparent. The major Peronist labor organizations, including the 62 Organizaciones, figure in the correspondence, as does the Consejo Coordinador y Supervisor de Peronismo. There are letters and reports sent to Perón by one of the earliest Peronist guerrilla movements, the Fuerzas Armadas Peronistas (FAP), as well as one letter from the much larger armed Peronist organization, the Montoneros. The series also has two drafts of a significant letter sent by Perón to President John F. Kennedy, then newly-elected, in 1961.

The papers contain a number of articles and speeches by Perón, and these are described in the Speeches and Writings series. This series also includes the outlines of lectures given by Perón in the 1930s on the Russo-Japanese War of 1905. Less important writings by Perón, such as communiqués and memoranda, are grouped in the Peronist Movement File, which also contains materials relating to Isabel Perón and Jose Lopez Rega. This file has a short handwritten declaration by Evita Perón as well.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into eight series: Biographical file, Correspondence, Speeches and Writings, Peronist Movement File, Subject File, Photographs, Printed Matter, and Oversize Materials.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Juan Atilio Bramuglia papers, Hoover Institution Archives
Luis Fernando Calviño papers, Hoover Institution Archives
Américo Ghioldi papers, Hoover Institution Archives
Hipólito Jesus Paz papers, Hoover Institution Archives

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes article and clippings, certificate of copyright, legal and tax records, arranged alphabetically by physical form.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Formerly security-classified records of the U.S. government, released in full or in part. Arranged chronologically by date of release by Hoover.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photocopies of U.S. Department of State Foreign Service despatches. One from the American Embassy in Buenos Aires to the Department of State, dated 14 September 1959, has the subject "Dominican Foreign Minister Promises Action Against Peron." The other, from the American Embassy in Ciudad Trujillo [Dominican Republic] to the Department of State, dated 14 October 1959, has the subject "Conversation with Acting Foreign Minister Balaguer," and includes a memorandum of conversation between Vice President Joaquin Balaguer and Henry Dearborn (Chargé d'Affaires).
